natural problem: When Trilisa takes pictures, they turn out with probability $\frac{1}{5}$. She wants to take enough pictures so that the probability of at least one turning out is at least $\frac{3}{4}$. How few pictures can she take to accomplish this?
natural solution: The probability that at least one picture turns out is $1$ minus the probability that all the pictures do not turn out. Since the probability that one picture will not turn out is $\frac{4}{5}$, the probability that $n$ pictures all do not turn out is $\left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^n$.
Thus the smallest allowable value of $n$ is $\boxed{7}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 1 / 5"
and h1 : "1 - p powr n \<ge> 3 / 4"
shows  "\<exists>n. n \<ge> 7"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When Trilisa takes pictures, they turn out with probability $\frac{1}{5}$. She wants to take enough pictures so that the probability of at least one turning out is at least $\frac{3}{4}$. How few pictures can she take to accomplish this? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 The probability that at least one picture turns out is $1$ minus the probability that all the pictures do not turn out. Since the probability that one picture will not turn out is $\frac{4}{5}$, the probability that $n$ pictures all do not turn out is $\left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^n$.
 So we want $$\left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^n<\frac{1}{4}\Rightarrow 4^{n+1}<5^n$$
 We see that $4^7>5^6$, but $4^8<5^7$.
 Thus the smallest allowable value of $n$ is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 1 / 5"
and h1 : "1 - p powr n \<ge> 3 / 4"
shows  "\<exists>n. n \<ge> 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a probability $p = \frac{1}{5}$, find the smallest integer $n$ such that $1 - p^n \geq \frac{3}{4}$. The final answer is $n \geq 7$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "p = 1 / 5"
and h1 : "1 - p ^ n \<ge> 3 / 4"
shows  "n \<ge> 7"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When Trilisa takes pictures, they turn out with probability $\frac{1}{5}$. She wants to take enough pictures so that the probability of at least one turning out is at least $\frac{3}{4}$. How few pictures can she take to accomplish this? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 The probability that at least one picture turns out is $1$ minus the probability that all the pictures do not turn out. Since the probability that one picture will not turn out is $\frac{4}{5}$, the probability that $n$ pictures all do not turn out is $\left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^n$.
 So we want $$\left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^n<\frac{1}{4}\Rightarrow 4^{n+1}<5^n$$
 We see that $4^7>5^6$, but $4^8<5^7$.
 Thus the smallest allowable value of $n$ is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "p = 1 / 5"
and h1 : "1 - p ^ n \<ge> 3 / 4"
shows  "n \<ge> 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A probability of success is $\frac{1}{5}$. What is the smallest number of trials needed so that the probability of at least one success is at least $\frac{3}{4}$? The final answer is 7 trials.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
and p :: real
assumes h0 : "0 < p"
and h1 : "p < 1"
and h2 : "p = 1 / 5"
and h3 : "1 - (1 - p) powr n \<ge> 3 / 4"
shows  "n \<ge> 7"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When Trilisa takes pictures, they turn out with probability $\frac{1}{5}$. She wants to take enough pictures so that the probability of at least one turning out is at least $\frac{3}{4}$. How few pictures can she take to accomplish this? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 The probability that at least one picture turns out is $1$ minus the probability that all the pictures do not turn out. Since the probability that one picture will not turn out is $\frac{4}{5}$, the probability that $n$ pictures all do not turn out is $\left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^n$.
 So we want $$\left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^n<\frac{1}{4}\Rightarrow 4^{n+1}<5^n$$
 We see that $4^7>5^6$, but $4^8<5^7$.
 Thus the smallest allowable value of $n$ is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
and p :: real
assumes h0 : "0 < p"
and h1 : "p < 1"
and h2 : "p = 1 / 5"
and h3 : "1 - (1 - p) powr n \<ge> 3 / 4"
shows  "n \<ge> 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A coin has a probability of $p=\frac{1}{5}$ of landing heads. Find the minimum number of times $n$ the coin must be flipped to ensure that the probability of getting at least one head is at least $\frac{3}{4}$. The final answer is $n \geq 7$.

theorem
fixes p :: real and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "p = 1 / 5"
and h1 : "1 - (1 - p) ^ n \<ge> 3 / 4"
shows  "n \<ge> 7"
a_3.formal solution:

theorem
fixes p :: real and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "p = 1 / 5"
and h1 : "1 - (1 - p) ^ n \<ge> 3 / 4"
shows  "n \<ge> 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A coin has a probability of $\frac{1}{5}$ of landing heads. What is the minimum number of times the coin must be flipped to have at least a $\frac{3}{4}$ probability of getting at least one head? The final answer is 7.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 1/5"
and h1 : "(\<Sum>k\<in>{0..n}. (1 - p)^k * p) \<ge> 3/4"
and h2 : "(\<Sum>k\<in>{0..(n-1)}. (1 - p)^k * p) < 3/4"
shows  "n = 7"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When Trilisa takes pictures, they turn out with probability $\frac{1}{5}$. She wants to take enough pictures so that the probability of at least one turning out is at least $\frac{3}{4}$. How few pictures can she take to accomplish this? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 The probability that at least one picture turns out is $1$ minus the probability that all the pictures do not turn out. Since the probability that one picture will not turn out is $\frac{4}{5}$, the probability that $n$ pictures all do not turn out is $\left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^n$.
 So we want $$\left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^n<\frac{1}{4}\Rightarrow 4^{n+1}<5^n$$
 We see that $4^7>5^6$, but $4^8<5^7$.
 Thus the smallest allowable value of $n$ is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 1/5"
and h1 : "(\<Sum>k\<in>{0..n}. (1 - p)^k * p) \<ge> 3/4"
and h2 : "(\<Sum>k\<in>{0..(n-1)}. (1 - p)^k * p) < 3/4"
shows  "n = 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a sequence of Bernoulli trials with success probability $p = \frac{1}{5}$, find the smallest number of trials $n$ such that the probability of at least one success is at least $\frac{3}{4}$. The final answer is $n = 7$.

a_5.informal problem: Suppose the probability of an event occurring is $\frac{1}{5}$. What is the minimum number of times the event must occur (n) so that the probability of it occurring at least once is at least $\frac{3}{4}$? The final answer is $n \geq 7$.

shows  "n \<ge> 7"
